H0.text: Ozone is formed when water vapor condenses into stratus clouds that are in contact with the ground.

H1.text: Methane forms as a result of water vapor condensing into stratus clouds that are in contact with the ground.

H2.text: Fog forms as a result of water vapor condensing into stratus clouds that are in contact with the ground.

H3.text: Smoke is formed when water vapor condenses into stratus clouds that are in contact with the ground.

A4.text: Fog appears when water vapor (water in its gaseous form) condenses.

A5.text: Fog can form at lower humidities and can sometimes fail to form with relative humidity at 100%.

A6.text: These clouds are essentially above-ground fog formed either through the lifting of morning fog or through cold air moving at low altitudes.
